bug.short_desc: [DeleteFromSupport] Deleting a connection whose source/target is canonical automatically deletes the element

long_desc.thetext:
Let's say you had the following scenario... On a non-canonical diagram, you have a non-canonical shape that contains canonical border item. There is a non-canonical connection from the border item to another shape. If you delete the connection with the delete key, you would expect it to just be deleted from the diagram, but instead it deletes the relationship from the model.
The reason is that ConnectionEditPolicy.shouldDeleteSemantic() returns true if one of the ends is canonical. Actually, it should figure out if the connector itself is canonical.

I already committed a fix that modifies the behavior of the ConnectionEditPolicy and DeleteFromDiagramAction so that the semantic element is deleted only if both source and target's containers are canonical. This is still not the real correct behavior, so I will leave this bugzilla open.
We need to figure out a way if the connection will be created canonically to really fix this.
Moving to the next release, GMF 2.1.

bug.short_desc: [misc] Eclipse-3.2.1 TextEditor no longer auto-sizes help descriptions

long_desc.thetext:
Previously (3.1.1) code-completion and context-HelpText for the generic TextEditor framework behaved this way for CNTL-SPACE help: 1) displayed a list of (developer generated) possible matches 2) as user scrolled through list, detailed description window showed details
NOTE: the detailed description window *used* to auto-size to attempt to display all text. Now it is fix-sized (quite small) and hence cuts-off most text. - worse, no horizontal or vertical scroll bars to see all detailed text.
This is a significant regression to the usefullness of contextHelp/completion.

The vertical size of the code assist help was and still is triggereed by the vertical size of the completion popup which can be changed by the user.
We only apply a max size.
The size is OK for me - can you please provide test cases and attach pictures.
>- worse, no horizontal or vertical scroll bars to see all detailed text. There was never a scroll bar and hence no regression here.
I was testing using the Java editor. The text editor does not show this.

I dont understand the preceeding comment - are you saying you see autosize in the 3.2.1 TextEditor framework ? - note that JavaEditor does not auto-size, but it does Auto-Wrap
TextEditor now (3.2.1) does not auto-size, and also does not auto-wrap. - used to auto-size in 3.1.1 (hence auto-wrap was not needed).
I'm talking about a concrete example/use case that shows the problem.
It really depends how the parts are plugged together and that's why we need to know where and how the framework code is used.
Created an attachment (id=52947) 321 TextEditor CTL-SPC completion (truncated text)
Created an attachment (id=52948) 311 TextEditor CTL-SPC completion (long text)
Created an attachment (id=52949) 3x1 JavaEditor CTL-SPC completion (wrapped text)
added pictures of TextEditor 311 long-text, 321 fixed-size truncated-text, and 3x1 JavaEditor wrapped-text.
Sorry, I cannot see any difference between picture 1 and 2. And I'd bet the last one with the Java editor is either 3.2 or newer and not 3.1.

Created an attachment (id=53001) 311 TextEditor CTL-SPC completion (long text)
correct image
Yes, that better shows the bug that was in 3.1 ;-)

OK, if I like the 3.1 bug :-), can I get closer to that behaviour by setting or affecting the maximum details windows size ?
The current 3.2 window is *really* small, much to small for interesting details. Even worse, 1) it is *not* resizeable 2) it does *not* have horizontal or vertical scrollbars
Hence much details text is unviewable.
The previous 311 behaviour showed most text, most of the time, and was "better" in my view (and in a customer reporting a problem/defect against the new 3.2 behaviour.)

>can I get closer to that behaviour by setting or >affecting the maximum details windows size ? You mean in your code? As a user you can make the proposal window bigger: the help takes the same size.
> 1) it is *not* resizeable 2) it does *not* have >horizontal or vertical scrollbars As you already know there's a bug report for that.

It is the detailed help window that is (now, in 3.21) too small. - I assume there is no programmatic way to increase it ? - and as per my previous comment the user cannot resize it or scroll it.
PS: How do I (programatically) set it to auto-wrap its displayed text ? - that would help (with the width problem), - but is not a real overall fix since with lots of text user cannot see all the help.

It is the detailed help window that is (now, in 3.21) too small. - I assume there is no programmatic way to increase it ? - and as per my previous comment the user cannot resize it or scroll it.
PS: How do I (programatically) set it to auto-wrap its displayed text ? - that would help (with the width problem), - but is not a real overall fix since with lots of text user cannot see all the help.

See SourceViewer.getInformationControlCreator(...): there you can create your own control that ingores setting the size and resizes at your will. Most likely a subclass of DefaultInformationControl.
>PS: How do I (programatically) set it to auto-wrap its displayed text ? If you use DefaultInformationControl add SWT.WRAP to the style (not the shellStyle).
Clients can show the hover as big as they want and not being able to focus and scroll the additional info is covered by bug 112921.

adding SWT.WRAP is not enough, it does not take effect. It also requires an IInformationPresenter, and there is not an available implementation class (HTMLTextPresenter is internal) A may is needed to simply force wrapping of text inside the new (much smaller) details window.
As well, how can I force my own larger size? Within my createInformationControl I create a DefaultInformationControl dic and tried setting dic.setSize(x,y) and dic.setSizeConstraints with no apparant affect.
right now, this remains an unacceptable regression since most of my detailed text is not visible (as it used to be in 3.1.x)

note: using the (internal) HTMLTextPresenter to test SWT.WRAP shows that WRAP then works, but HTMLTextPresenter is not acceptable for "normal" text since it flows everything onto one continuous long line and ignores CRLF linebreaks (as HTML does).
Hence the 2 problems persist: 1) how to easily force wrap 2) how to expand the details window to be somewhat larger (*not* the list selection window, just the details window).

also, since we are getting close to shipping a product based on eclipse321 with this regressed (to me and my customer) behaviour, it is becoming very important - at least that I can identify a valid workaround.
as is, the code-completion detailed help window has gone from being almost always displaying the full contents to now almost always only showing a very small amount.

I get the enlarged size working: 1) need to call parent.setSize(w,h) 2) new size must be diferent (bigger) to have effect Then, the ehaviour is almost like the old 311 behaviour (auto-resize to attempt to fit all text, etc).

Instead of setting the size you can also create a subclass of DefaultInformationControl and ignore (or adjust) the setSize and setSizeConstraints methods.
I see that we changed your behavior but that behavior was due to a bug and we had to fix it. The correct solution is really to provide your own information control.
Support for SWT.WRAP wasn't working correctly at all using 3.1 or earlier.
Regarding the presenter: I suggest to simply copy it as PDE does. The reason for not making it API is that it only handles the subset we need and not full HTML i.e. one of your favourite tag might not be supported.

yes, you may have had a bug (for multi-monitor systems?), but the previous default behaviour, autosizing to fit as much text as the display permits, should have been retain since that is *much* more desireable as default behaviour. the 3.2.1 change to have a SMALL non-resizable window is a significant regression.
I have opened Bugzilla-13 to track that it is not easy to set SWT.WRAP to adjust for this new 321 behavior, since there is no default text presenter. Having most context help developers copy the PDE presenter into their own code is not as appropriate as having a default text presenter available - especially since the 321 small size will force *many* developers to have to do this (and restest/maintain it as the TextEditor framework changes over time).
To track each of these various independent context help difficulties I have opened the following (including this report): Bugzilla-162763: 3.2.1 regression which eliminated autosizing. Bugzilla-162767: user cannot f2 focus to the details window, Bugzilla-163552: details window not having resize nor scroll bars. Bugzilla-163553: context help detail window needs default presenter for wrap

The main fix was exactly to support SWT.WRAP (see bug 117602). Another problem was that setting the size of the hover to the one of the list popup didn't correctly work. This change is not new to 3.2.1 but is in since M5 without any other client complaining so far.
How did you originally (for 3.1.x) setup the content assistant i.e. how did the information control creator look like?

From which class does your source viewer config inherit? If it inherits from SourceViewerConfiguration then I wondering why you'd need HTMLTextPresenter to use SWT.WRAP. The fix we put into 3.2 for bug 117602 should allow you to do this without a presenter. If this isn't working then that's a bug. Maybe we didn't test with the code assist hover but just with the normal hover. This needs to be investigated.
>I still dont know how to change the hover flyover window size. The way code assist and its hover window is implemented since more than four years (yes indeed) is that the popup size is intended to be resized and then this size is applied to the additional hover help i.e. the size is set on the hover window by the framework. Due to a bug this wasn't correctly done in all scenarios but now is. The only way a client is intended to override this behavior is to provide a subclass of DefaultInformationControl and ignore setting the size and instead set its own size.

yes, setting SWT.WRAP with presenter=null works. That is as major help.
without wrapping I can (now) get the previous autosize behaviour using the code snippet i pasted in in my previous post. still dont know why that works.
I am tracking the hover/flyover issues separately: Bugzilla-149519: cannot F2 or resize hover/flyover window.
NOTE: this defect was originaly opened to track the completion proposal details window no longer autosizing. Give my workaround snippet works (but I dont know why), I would be happy to close this bug report if you can explain why (and hence I can count on the workaround continuing to provide autosizing).
given my SWT.NONE workaround works (at least in 3.2.1), i am changing priority to minor.
it appears the current (3.1.2) behaviour is here to stay. - i have a workaround that works - so will close defect Even though i think the change in behaviour is a regression.

bug.short_desc: Equinox OSGi Framework launch configurations fail when using OSGiMin1.1/RM JRE.

long_desc.thetext:
Within the IDE, if an Equinox OSGi Framework launch configuration is pointed to an OSGiMin1.1/RM JRE (within the Settings tab on the IDe window), the runtime fails to launch with the following error:
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: java.io.FileFilter at java.lang.J9VMInternals.verifyImpl(Native Method) at java.lang.J9VMInternals.verify(J9VMInternals.java:54) at java.lang.J9VMInternals.initialize(J9VMInternals.java:115)
If a -noverify JVM command line argument is added, the runtime fails to launch with the following exception:
java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: java/lang/Runtime.removeShutdownHook(Ljava/lang/Thread;)Z at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.takeDownSplash(Main.java:1604) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:1003) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:952)
The JRE used to create this condition was based on the IBM WECE 6.1.1 Max/RM distribution.
The minimum JRE needed in order to successfully launch an Eclipse OSGi Framework using a launch configuration within the IDE appears to be Foundation 1.0.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 150669 ***

(In reply to comment #1) > *** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 150669 ***
Thank you. I never would have made the connection.
The other bug report was issued against 3.2. The fix apparently did not get into 3.2.1 and there is no target milestone listed. Will this be applied to 3.3?
John, the patch did not make it into 3.2.x. Please voice your request to include a fix in bug 150669. We need to get a committer of the org.eclipse.platform team to review and release the fix.
Note that bug 159122 calls for this statup.jar code to be moved to org.eclipse.equinox.startup. We should take action on that but it still does not solve the 3.2.x problem.

bug.short_desc: [DND] Activate views/editors during drag

long_desc.thetext:
3.2
Currently, when dragging an object from one part (view or editor) to another, the user needs to ensure both parts are frontmost in their stack before starting the drag.
It would be nice if an obscured part could be brought to front (i.e. activated) during the drag by hovering over its tab.
This is particularly important if the drag needs to happen between two parts in the same part stack.
DnD is fairly prevalent in some of Jazz views and editors, and we're starting to experience the current inability to activate parts during a drag as a usability problem.

Kim,
if you're talking about the SWT drag handling (used when starting a drag from Ithe tree control in a view, for example) then this would require some delicate work...the drag events are only sent to controls with registered SWT Drop Targets.
I'm not sure if the WB is even in the loop (i.e. I'm not sure if we can even detect that such a drag has been started/finished so as to install a MouseMove listener). Note that this is not normal behaviour for at least some of the platforms (Windows at least). I'm not saying that it shouldn't be...;-).
I'm just starting some talks with Duong (now wearing his spanky new SWT har...;-) about some of the existing issues with SWT's Dnd infrastructure. I'll bring this up with him to at least find out what some of the answers are...
I filed this (not Kim - don't shoot the messenger ;-)). Please drop by for an explanation if it's unclear.

If we can -guarantee- that we can trap both the 'start' and 'end' drag events then we should be able to do something along these lines:
on 'Start': Add a mouse (hover?) listener that on a hover (i.e. some amount of time without a mouse move) checks whether or not the cursor is over a 'switch area' (CTabFolder tab, Perspective?) and, if so, causes the appropriate activation to take place.
On 'End': remove te ilstener
Note that the naive implementation (i.e. only acts on visible CTabFolder tabs) is likely to be just the start. Folks will immediately want the chevron menu for both ViewStacks and the EditorStacks to work as well.
Nock raised the interesting question of whether we should extend this to Perspectives as well (i.e. let a drag start in a view in one perspective and end in a view in a different perspective). Comments?
Yet another 'hover to activate' request

bug.short_desc: Wrong version number in plug-in

long_desc.thetext: org.eclipse.tptp.platform.models was shipped with version 4.2.2 in TPTP V4.2.1 but the version number in HEAD was not updated to match. In order for the version in TPTP V4.3 to be installed by Update Manager then the version needs to be incremented to 4.2.100.
Fix checked in.

bug.short_desc: [hovering] Per default F2 should show make a hover stick like in the Java editor

long_desc.thetext:
The code-completion and context-HelpText for the generic TextEditor framework behaves this way for flyover/completion help: 1) flyover displays a list of (developer generated) help text - no F2-focus option, no horiz/vert scrollbars if text too big for window 2) CTL-SPC displays a list of (developer generated) possible matches - with horiz/vert scrollbars if the list is too big for available window = but without F2-focus option - as user scrolls through list, detailed description window shows details = but without scrollbars if window text too big (same problem as flyover)
Since some lists and/or descriptions may be very big, the generic TextEdit framework should have the same feature the JavaEditor has: 1) F2-focus and resize+vert+horizontal scrollbars on flyover description 2) completion resize+vert+horizontal scrollbars for list - and preferrably description resize+vert+horizontal scrollbars
NOTE: the JavaEditor flyover-help has "F2-Focus", while code completion has horiz/vert scrollbars.

With flyover you mean the hover that for example shows Javadoc? The stuff is in place as API (e.g. the command) to provide F2 help in other editors but currently not hard-wired to show the same information in the F2 window. It would probably make sense to connect it as it is in the Java editor and let others allow to plug-in different behavior if needed.
>2) CTL-SPC displays a list of (developer generated) possible matches >- with horiz/vert scrollbars if the list is too big for available window > = but without F2-focus option Do you mean F2 for the window that displays the list? We won't add this. You can use the arrow key or the mouse to activate it. Note that 'F2' does not mean "give focus".
>- as user scrolls through list, detailed description window shows details > = but without scrollbars if window text too big (same problem as flyover) This is tracked by bug 112921.
>2) completion resize+vert+horizontal scrollbars for list >- and preferrably description resize+vert+horizontal scrollbars Are you saying that the window with the list does not have scrollbars? About which editor's content assist are you talking? The framework code sets the SWT flags to get the scrollbars and enable resize behavior and this can't be overridden by clients. Can you attach a test case and/or screen shot?
Didn't mean to mark as REMIND.

Bug 149519 covers the F2 push down.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 149519 ***
I'd be interested about the proposal popup (list) with no scroll bars. Please add your comments to this bug. We might reopen it later when we have more info.

no, i was not clear and you misunderstood. 1) I was complaining that 3.2.1 TextEditor framework completion help **details** window: - has no F2-focus option, - has no horiz/vert scrollbars if text too big for window - and in 321 has droped autosize and hence much details text cannot be seen. - NOTE: the completion popup list is fine (truncated, but scrolls and resize) = but when user selects one of the proposed options, then details window is too small and no longer auto-sizes. 2) I was complaining that **hover** flyover help window: - has no F2-focus option, - has no horiz/vert scrollbars if text too big for window - has no resize ability
I was **not** suggesting elimination of the scrollbars from #1 completion popup list of proposals (that is critical to retain, along with its resize option).

yes, bug-149515 addresses the need for F2-focus for hover/flyover.
my other concern here was for #2 CTL-SPC code completions and its *details* window. user can resize the proposals window, but cannot do anything to resize the details explanation window. probably F2-focus is not the answer, probably the details window should support resize/scroll, covered by bug-163552.
So lets leave this bug as dup of the F2 for hover/flyover requirement.
closing since being tracked elsewhere.

bug.short_desc: ProgressListener.completed called multiple times for same document

long_desc.thetext:
ProgressListener.completed(event2) is getting called multiple times when loading a document that contains Frames.
Place a breakpoint in MozBrowserEditor.handleProgressCompleted() Go to a site with Frames
Why this bug has no answer ?
Does this article "MSDN - How To Determine When a Page Is Done Loading in WebBrowser Control" answer our question ? MSDN Article : http://support.microsoft.com/?scid=kb%3Ben-us%3B180366&x=19&y=12

Here the part of the article which seems important for us: >The top-level frame fires the DocumentComplete in the end. So, to check if a >page is done downloading, you need to check if the IDispatch* parameter is same >as the IDispatch of the WebBrowser control. > >For Visual Basic, here is code that performs this check: > >Private Sub WebBrowser1_DocumentComplete(ByVal pDisp As Object, > URL As Variant) > If (pDisp Is WebBrowser1.Object) Then > Debug.Print "Web document is finished downloading" > End If >End Sub

This bug is actually in the context of Mozilla and our embedded implementation. It is in the process of getting fixed.
As for the MSDN pointers, thanks for that because after this milestone we want to start looking at IE.

Hello,
Can you tell me if this bug has been studied in the IE context ??
Thanks

The ATF team never owned the I.E. browser support. The I.E. support is owned by the SWT team, so your question would need to be asked to that team. My guess the answer to the question is no. The SWT interfaces don't seem to have a concept of a completed page, when many pages have multiple frames
In Eclipse 3.3, the Mozilla browser support has been moved into SWT component. In the process the ProgressListener support didn't make the transfer. We have submitted a patch to bug 178410 for this problem. This bug is not longer valid, since we no longer own the Mozilla Browser support. We should look at closing or transferring the bug.

Thanks for your answer.
Yes please, could you transfer this Bug to the SWT Team ?

I opened bug 178410 in order to better implement the progress notifications in the Mozilla impl. While that bug specifically references Mozilla, any changes there would also have to be reflected in the other browsers as well, to put them all on the same page. Take a look at that bug.
Closing this bug as INVALID since we no longer own the browser impl.

bug.short_desc: EAR is always required for application clients

long_desc.thetext: The Web Services wizard always requires that clients being generated into an application client project also have a corresponding EAR. This EAR is created with the application client project added during the assemble phase. The EAR should be made optional for application clients. A good analogy is the Java project case where if a user provides a pure Java project as input, no EAR is ever created.

J2EE allows both standalone (eg. client app jar) and packaged applications (eg. an EAR containing a client app jar) to be deployed to a container. The Web Service wizard bases its decision to require, or not require, an EAR on the target server's declaration of requiring, or not requiring, EARs for the purpose of deployment. As far as I know, server tools does not specify the requirement, or lack thereof, of an EAR per module type. I will chat with the Server Tools team (Tim) about whether we need to do this. The alternative is to special-case our logic to make the EAR optional when assembling/deploying app clients despite what the target server's opinion is about needing EARs, but I'm not too comfy with this idea - not yet, anyways...
Thanks - CB.

Correct, this requirement doesn't come from the framework. I assume it was with a specific server adapter? We'll have to look at what the WS team uses to determine if an EAR is required, if this makes sense, and if the specific server adapter is returning correct information.

bug.short_desc: [FieldAssist] Need support for arbitrary locations

long_desc.thetext: I would like to be able to place my decoration along left/right edge of the field at random position. Right now, the only options are beginning, center and end alignments. My editor is form based editor (as opposed to text editor) with several widgets displayed simultaneously. Each of the widgets (I use StyledText mostly) can have some (sometimes large number) of associated "things". Things can be "standard", like errors, search results and bookmarks, as well as specific to our product. I would like to display decorations for those states, but I do not want them to overlap. I am using our in-house solution, which I would like to replace with FieldDecorators.

Are you referring to DecoratedField or the new ControlDecoration in 3.3 M3? ControlDecoration intends to provide this behavior in the future, and in fact there are some positioning methods that have been made protected for future experimentation.
See also bug #162497. I'm not marking this as a duplicate since it is a request for general opening up of the placement code vs. the specific request for positioning by table row.

Alex, if you wanted to play with this now, see the method ControlDecoration.getDecorationRectangle(Control targetControl).
This is the intended hook for custom decoration placement, although I have done nothing yet to try it out with alternate locations, as we are focusing on the base function for M3. Note that the API is still marked experimental and may evolve throughout 3.3....
cc'ing Kevin
Alex, I'm assuming there is enough support for you in the current implementation. Please annotate this bug if there is not, as we are freezing API in M6.

In fact I did not have time to even start experimenting with that class, Susan. Speak of being efficient ;-( I will wait for post M6 and hopefully all the interfaces and classes will be easier to find then.

I would like to comment on ControlDecoration functionality that I have seen so far:
1. In its present form it only supports 6 positions. We would prefer to be able to specify random position (in terms of offset from the top left or right corner)
2. It would be nice if there was a way to detect when user clicks mouse on the decoration, or on the area reserved for decoration(s) (along left or right edge)
3. Would be nice to be able to provide a way custom draw instead (or in addition to) of using images as decorations.
I will attempt to subclass (by example) ControlDecoration to show you how to do #1 and #2. I really don't see providing #3 in the near future. If needed, you could render onto an image.
Thank you Susan. In my custom solution I am creating images on the fly... thought it would be easier on resources (and perhaps faster) if I could just draw on DC instead. May be not though...

It likely would be more efficient to skip the image part, but I think dynamically rendered decorations are kind of stretching the intent of ControlDecoration, so I don't see doing owner draw in the API if you can successfully do it in client code.
If this proves to be a common pattern, we can revisit. I'll still investigate items 1 & 2...
Sounds good -- I will be looking forward to this.

Hi, Alex. I have an example that shows (1) and (2). (1) arbitrary placed locations - can be done using the existing API, overriding the protected method getDecorationRectangle(control). (2) would require new API - Since the ControlDecoration may be rendering on any parent widget in the control hierarchy, it would be complicated for a client to implement this behavior on their own. Most likely we'd add API to let you install a MouseListener on the control decoration.
I have not yet released any code since #2 requires new API, and all API changes must get PMC approval at this stage in the release. So my question is whether your comment "would be nice" on item (2) is from a use case in your product, or just a "would be nice someday."
If it's a real requirement, I will refine the API and submit a request to the PMC. I'd just as soon add it now while ControlDecoration is still new, but I don't want to do it without understanding the priority and usage.

Regarding #2, here is the usecase: The editor(s) in our product are form-based editors. They display multiple controls/widgets. These widgets allow user to view/edit or otherwise modify some data attribute. There are various additional properties that can be associated with most attributes, generic, like errors, bookmarks and tasks, and product-specific such as data correlation sites. All of these are displayed in various forms of text styles inside StyledText-based attributes (other widgets also have some way of displaying them). Because the editor is form based editor, we want these attributes to be displayed along the left (and right) edges of the widget to which they "belong". We already do it now, using our own mechanism. The ultimate goal is to have annotation areas associated with a widget, as opposed to the entire editor. User should be able to click on the little decorations to navigate directly to the location inside an attribute. Can people live without it? Yes they can. Should they have this functionality? Yes they should... Hence, "nice to have".

Thanks, Alex. I can see that it would be useful function in general. Gee, there's a "thingie" there telling me something. I want to work with it. And especially in the error or info case, you might want to navigate to the specific part in the text.
I'm only reticent so that this doesn't feature creep into something it's not. For example, I can't see dragging and dropping it, but clicking on it seems within the realm of a decoration.
The most compelling reason in my mind to offer the API is that you'd have to rely on the underlying implementation to be able to do it from the outside (walk the parent tree and figure out where the decoration is located).
So I think it's a reasonable request. Kevin McG - thoughts? I'm gut checking with you before proposing new API for the PMC.

You are correct, this should not be anything more than I have described. In fact, it ought to be almost identical to annotation mechanisms present in JFace, complete with markers, annotations types and specifications and so on... I wish I could use annotations, but they sit on top of IDocuments and editors, whereas we don't have IDocument and the editor is multi-widget. So if we could mimic the most common things from annotations (or somehow marry the annotations support with ControlDecoration, even better if more time consuming) that would suffice.
Please let me know if I can help further.

Yes, I can see a possible relationship there. These features (click support, arbitrary placement) are allowing you to build a ruler of sorts for a multi-control editor. And annotations could be used to populate the control decorations.
For now, I think it is important to limit the ControlDecoration API to general use features, and I think placement and mouse listeners are fairly general purpose.
After we settle what's done for 3.3, it may be worth investigating whether there should be code that allows for more integration. Field assist in general arose from taking platform text features and making them more general (non-document oriented).
cc'ing Kim for comment
This seems entirely reasonable from my perspective.

Aside: should we branch a new bug to discuss the problem of selection listening?
I understand the desire to back the ControlDecoration with behaviour. It could be quite useful in an number of places. I worry though about feature creep. My concerns are:
1. Too open
There is a real tendency for this to be come "the one hammer to hit all nails with". Most of the controls in Eclipse have standard and predictable interaction behaviour. Eg. text controls, toolbar items, etc. You don't know what they'll do app wise, but you do know how to interact with them. There are a small number like the editor strip that introduces new controls (e.g. breakpoint, bookmarks, etc) but these benefit from being relatively small in number, used pervasively so people can learn them, and provide only very simple interaction (click to add/remove, and a menu).
Allowing arbitrary mouse listening on the ControlDecoration opens up quite widely a set of uses which we hadn't envisioned. I don't feel comfortable with it becoming "a picture which you can put anywhere, to which can do anything".
Lets say all we provide is a single "selected" event instead of the raw mouse event. Is this enough for the new requirements? (Even at that I'm not sure I'd be comfortable with how its been opened up).
2. Consistency in interaction behaviour
We need a common language for interaction in the UI. Is it single click to activate? Double click? App dependent?
More so, all uses of the "error" decoration should ideally have the same click behaviour in the IDE (e.g. take you to the error description, allow click fix, etc). Maybe that's just a style guide issue but another approach is that you subclass if you want behaviour, so there becomes an "ErrorDecoration" class that has code for showing errors on click.
3. Feedback
We'd either need an alt image to tell you the item has been selected, or cursor change to the "hand" to tell you that clicking on it will do something.
4. Accessibility
We need to consider accessibility. Are you going to be able to tab to it to trigger its click behaviour? I don't think so, its not a real control and can't live in the tab sequence. I don't see how to directly make this accessible. Perhaps nice developers will add equivalent key sequences, or a menu in the control. But there's nothing to tie one to the other so a user can learn what the accessible alternative is.
5. Popup Menu? Menu bar menu?
The items in the editor LHS strip have popup menus associated with them. Do we expect ControlDecorations to have these too? If you allow clicking on them to do something, then why not a menu? Generally the rule is that you shouldn't have items in popup menus that you can't get from a menu bar.
Something to note is that items in the editor strip also live in other views (e.g. Breakpoint view, bookmark view). This is their primary "home" and they happen as a convenience to show up in the editor too, which relaxes some constraints on them. In their specific views they have menu bar entries which then they can get away without in the editor strip.

Alex, I have opened up bug #176198 to address the request for mouse click events, which we will address for 3.3.
After some discussion, we have decided to defer the support for arbitrary locations. Our rationale is: - Existing eclipse decorators have the same constraints on decorator position, and if we are to solve the issue of needing more slots, we want to address the general problem, not just the problem with ControlDecoration - Allowing arbitrary placement opens up the behavior too generally, especially for a first iteration of API. It also introduces complexities such as scrolling behavior, etc., that we don't want to address this late in the release. - We need to see more use cases in order to determine the appropriate API for specifying additional locations. - For your specific use case, it sounds as if using a ruler strip is more in line with what you are trying to achieve. There is a committed JDT plan item to open up support for these editor strips, so I suggest you contact Daniel Megert to determine what is available.

bug.short_desc: Detect undefined variables as warnings

long_desc.thetext:
I think that this behavior should be based on a configuration option which should include the current error_reporting settings like:
Undefined variables report () report undefined variables () do not report undefined variables () obey to PHP error reporting level
Yossi/Asi is this something we want to implement?
+1 -- phpeclipse has this feature already in 1.1.9. Adding it as something toggleable via a preferences page would be cool, but having it on by default would be a good first step if time is short.

bug.short_desc: [config] Graduate Configuration Admin Service implementation

long_desc.thetext: The Configuration Admin implementation in the incubator has been stable for several months now. I think it's time to look to graduate it.
Cool :-)
Who is going to do the reviews? Simon, can you point out exactly which code (CVS projects) are involved here?

Just one project is involved: /cvsroot/eclipse/equinox-incubator/org.eclipse.equinox.cm
In addition to reviews, we need to re-validate that this implementation still passes the TCK.
it would be great to get someone who has done an implemetation of Config Admin to review. Hmmm, wonder where we'd find one of those people...

(In reply to comment #5) > it would be great to get someone who has done an implemetation of Config Admin > to review. Hmmm, wonder where we'd find one of those people... >
Gosh, I don't know... I guess I will need to find some spare time...
BJ, have you had a chance to take a look? Can anyone else do a review as well?

Created an attachment (id=66045) First pass review changes and comments
Here are my first pass review comments. I have not really focussed on correctness with respect to the Config Admin spec in this pass. I focussed on thread safety, proper use of the core framework, general Java usage, etc.
I made a number of changes to the code in the patch and also added a number of TODO comments for areas which need larger attention.
With respect to thread safety, I made numerous changes to make instance variables final where possible. This should always be your first choice. The JMM makes thread safety guarantees for final instance variables after the constructor completes. All other instance variables need proper synchronization for read and write access. There are some TODOs where more attention is needed to thread safety.
Also, per spec section 5.2.4, I modified the code to remove the need for pending events waiting for the service reference of the Config Admin service.
Lets looks at discussing these changes/comments and then I will do a review against the Config Admin spec.
Thanks BJ -- much appreciated. Use of finals is a best practice here. I'll submit those changes and re-create your patch so we can look at something a bit smaller before doing a deeper dive.

The PluginManager code had a bug where it was using the Config Admin service reference instead of the ManagedService or ManagedServiceFactory reference. This is what led to all the complexity around the pending event code as it seemed like the config admin reference could be needed by the implementation prior to a getService call on the factory.
I've cleaned that logic up now and integrated the changes with your patch. I've also done some quick sanity tests and all seems well. I'll re-run the TCK when I get the chance, but for now I'm ok with committing this as it's moving things in the right direction and keeps future review in synch.
I've left in all your TODO comments and when I get the chance I'll collect them together in this bug and reply. Thanks.

I've gone through the other TODOs you left in your patch and they all look legitimate. I've created the following bugs to look at them:
bug 185978 - [config] Breakup ConfigurationAdminFactory bug 185979 - [config] Make ConfigurationDictionary threadsafe bug 185981 - [config] Improve ConfigurationStore implementation bug 185984 - [config] Thread safety in ManagedServiceTracker and ManagedServiceFactoryTracker bug 185985 - [config] Handle registration modifcations that change service.pid

I think this component is ready to graduate now. All the above bugs are now closed and I've re-run the TCK to validate. In addition I've added a test plug-in (org.eclipse.equinox.cm.test) to provide us with better coverage. It would be easy to integrate this with the rest of our testing infrastructure.
What do you think?
Tom and BJ should review before graduation

We should fix bug 209294 so events are piped through event admin properly before we graduate.
Go get 'em BJ/Tom.

attachment.desc: First pass review changes and comments

bug.short_desc: Europa: Jar Signing

long_desc.thetext:
Need to sign jars for Corona 1.0 GA
1. Jar signing The Eclipse Foundation, with help from the Eclipse project team, has set up an infrastructure that will enable you to sign your JAR files, as well as JAR files within a ZIP file. The files are signed by the Foundation, using a Foundation-owned code signing certificate. We will be extending signing privileges to one or two committers on each project.
How does it work?
1. You Project Lead must tell us (webmaster) who is allowed to sign JARs for your project.
2. When you've been granted signing privileges, you use an SSH client and connect to build.eclipse.org using your committer account as usual.
3. You must copy/move the files you wish to sign to the downloads staging area. We do not allow you to sign files from any other location.
4. You type a command that will add files to the signing queue. The queue is processed automatically, and you can get an e-mail notification when signing is complete.
5. You can then move the signed files from the staging area to your downloads area.
Detailed instructions on the signing process will be sent to those committers who are appointed as signers.
*** Bug 165651 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
requested jar signing privileges from Eclipse webmaster.
Eclipse webmaster has granted jar signing privileges to both Dennis and Pawel.

Having problems accessing staging area. Permission denied trying to copy/move files to staging area. * /home/data/httpd/download-staging.priv/technology
Sent email to Eclipse webmaster asking to verify access rights.
Manual jar signing works fine. Signing server and staging area are accessible. Automated jar signing will not be included in the build process for the moment.

bug.short_desc: Improve Sequence Diagram Usability

long_desc.thetext:
We have shown the sequence diagrams to several potential users, they usually do not understand what the diagram is depicting, but once they understand what it is, they think it could be useful if some improvements are made. With a number of improvements, this diagram could be useful to them:
1. Improve color coding. The color coding is not intuitive. Red usually indicates errors, but here, it just indicates a gap in time. The following color scheme should be used for the left column: red - errors yellow - warnings blue - information gray - gaps in logs We can mockup some designs to illustrate.
2. Show timestamps. This is probably the most important missing element that would help to clarify the purpose of the diagram.
We do NOT want to show every second or millasecond but we should have an algorithm to show every few seconds or minutes.
3. Users should be able to re-arrange the logs shown at the top-the order they are displayed is arbitrary, but it is much easier to visualize relationships when compoents that are calling each other are next to each other.
Also, color-coding and icons need to be described in a legend.
Resolving this as WONTFIX because it is no longer required by the consumer that requested it.

bug.short_desc: Prioritize Filter Properties Attribute Dropdown by usage (and other ones too)

long_desc.thetext:
The list of attributes in the Add Filter Property dialog box is huge and needs to be prioritized according to the liklihood that it will be used. Here is a recommended order:
1. Message - this will be the search string in 90% of searches and should be seleted by default
2. Priority - this is about 5% liklihood
3. If there is a thread ID key that can be used to differentiate thread IDs, this would be the next most common search
4. Timestamp
5. Everything else, alphabetized
This is for both IDE and Rcp
Resolving this as WONTFIX because it is no longer required by the consumer that requested it.

bug.short_desc: diagram appearance properties : apply a color property change to diagram, all shapes updated, undo only works for one shape

long_desc.thetext:
In a geoshape diagram if you change a diagram color property in the properties view that gets applied to all shapes in the diagram by color property - line color, fill color, or font color UNDO only applies to one of the shapes, you cannot undo for the change you just applied
For example, open the diagram editor, select a diagram with multiple shapes in the properties view, change the fill color notice the color changes for all the shapes on the diagram hit UNDO the undo works for only one of the shapes the user cannot unapply the change
Created an attachment (id=53494) fixing the undo problem
Fixed

bug.short_desc: DiagramEditor fails trying to add a null child caused by reentrant calls to AbstractEditPart.refreshChildren

long_desc.thetext: Happens when a complicated canonical refresh is needed. AbstractEditPart.refreshChildren() is called and (while the children are being matched in the loop), some commands are executed that invalidate the previous list of model children (a child becomes detached). Then, another refreshChildren() is executed, but the first one completes after this one, trying to create an editpart for a child that no longer exists. Such situation should be avoided.
Fix submitted.

bug.short_desc: NullPointerException in UpdateManager.firePainting(Rectangle)

long_desc.thetext:
Created an attachment (id=52951) proposed patch
adds an "else" check in removeUpdateListener(UpdateListener) for when the new size is 0. If so, a size-0 UpdateListener array is created.

bug.short_desc: Improve Import Symptom database flow.

long_desc.thetext:
1. Add the location where the symptom database will be downloaded from. 2. Add a button to to add and edit locations that will open the preferences panel. 3. Add an automatic option to the Import using and Target Format dropdowns. Try the most likely one, then if that doesn't work try the next most likely one and so on. When we have shown this panel to users, they had no idea which one to choose. 4. Location to import database too should refer to the filesystem, not the workspace. 5. Finish button should be OK. 6. Window should be wide enough to accommodate to reasonable-sized path without horizontal scrolling.
See attached mockup.
Created an attachment (id=52950) Mockup
What means automatic for the import and target import ? In other words, how would a user understand this option ?

Automatic should ideally mean that the system figures out which setting is correct.
If we are not able to do this, it means, the system should try the most likely one, then if that doesn't work the second most likely and so on. Most users will have no idea how to set these.

I understand but I don't think this will make the user less confused.
What about an Advanced button that hides these combo options ?

I don't think I understand. Users need to choose one, don't they? We can hide the setting if we can automatically detect which one they need to choose. Or if you're saying automatically detect and also hide the settings, that should work.

I'm not sure if Automatic is clear enough (the user would not know what settings were used), I think we should show the symptom format version beside the file name for the case where we know or we can identify by reading the top (several lines) of the file, otherwise show "unknown" and force the user to choose a format. This is for the source.
For the target it should always be the latest format (since 4.2 would be Symptom v2.0) so the user should change it if they want a different format.
This feature should probably also include the run in background option (in an Eclipse job) and also provide progress information like we do in the other import cases.

Let me summarize my suggestion on this:
- I agree with Valentina in comment 4 for introducing the options in Advanced tab or section
- Commenting to comment 6, sometimes the format could have been known to LTA. This is the case when the user/administrator/installer adds the download URL in the preference page of LTA. Beside asking the URL there, the format of the database should be asked as an optional entry field. You could display it, but really, most users would not care. Less is better. Besides, if you import from "Local Host", there is no way to know the format until the file is read.
- Commenting to comment 6, again, most users would not know or care about the format, if this is hidden in Advanced tab or button, it could be defaulted to the latest or preferred format (v2.0).
- Commenting to comment 6, I suggest to use the word "auto-detect" instead of "unknown" or "automatic" for Import Format entry field. Again, this choice should be hidden in Advanced tab or button, and should be the default value. Let the advanced users pay the price of changing the Import format. Most users would not care or see this option.
- I like comment 7 too.

We should be able in most cases to auto-detect the symptom format by just reading the top of the file, that's why I think auto-detect should be enabled by default.
Only if we cannot detect the source file type (and in that case we might not be able to import it at all) we should ask the user to provide the source type.
The target type should be by default set to the latest type supported by that specific workbench.
If you want to hide the types you could probably get rid completely of the source and target controls in the simple mode and show them only in the advanced mode, basically in most cases the only thing that the user has to do (and see) is to select the file (from local machine, FTP/HTTP or other future methods) and click finish (if the auto-detect works fine and the user doesn't want to use a different target format).
In the advanced mode I can see more features added in futures versions, like import filters (using XPath bases rules), multiple file import etc (similar features like those in Import Log wizard).
Would be good if we could provide a consistent import experience across different models/input formats where the common behavior would be provided through highly reusable components (covering both UI and non-UI functionality).

(In reply to comment #9)
I agree with almost all what Marius said. Just two points:
1. Quoting "Only if we cannot detect the source file type (and in that case we might not be able to import it at all) we should ask the user to provide the source type.". If we cannot detect the type, there can be three options: a. Let the system decide: The system should try with all known types in some order specified in Preference b. Let the user decide: Ask the user to select the type (in the Advance tab) c. Let the user choose: Ask the user if the system should do option a. or b.
I like and recommend option c.
2. I like Marius' idea of making the import experience consistent across different functions. For example, the importing of logs has some usability problem also (see bug 161779). There, it would be nice for the user not to have specify the log type before importing. I am wondering if we could achieve that, but that may be a different problem. But, it is worth looking into for usability reason.
Resolving this as WONTFIX because it is no longer required by the consumer that requested it.

If a file filter is created with folder from root file system (for example: /tmp) when expanding the filter, it seems to be displaying contents from /bin instead.
Javier that's yours
Yes, it is caused by the fix for bug 162511, and also prevents creating new folders and files from folders containing subfolders (bug 162878). Fixing 162878 should fix this bug as well.
What's weird is that ssh uses almost exactly the same code for filtering, but I'm not seing these problems in ssh. Or am I missing something?

> What's weird is that ssh uses almost exactly the same code for filtering, but > I'm not seing these problems in ssh. Or am I missing something?
The issue is in org.eclipse.rse.services.files.ftp.FTPService, the equivalent functionality for SSH is in org.eclipse.rse.services.ssh.files.SftpFileService; although they may use the same high level features, the implementation is different.
Separated implementation of getFile() and internalFetch() in FTPService. Now the folders are listed as expected.

Tested with I20061102-1200 Not sure if I did the same thing the reporter did, but the filters I created work as expected except that a filter that has "Show file only" selected still showed a subdirectory.

bug.short_desc: Publish team information in WBS for TDs

The ItemProvider for the consolidated view will be enhanced to provide the column data. 3. The publishing logic for the WBS will be modified to include the Team column if it's specified the prefernce for Team Allocation. 4. The Team column will be published at the right end at the WBS page. 5. Provide unambiguous names in published Team Allocation view: TBD.

bug.short_desc: /mdt and /modeling/mdt won't refresh

Denis:
Noticed this afternoon that symlinks don't appear to be working exactly as we'd expect. We had this as a symlink:
/modeling/mdt -> /mdt
and it seemed that the script that you use to check out from CVS to the web filesystem was always a version behind in /modeling/mdt, but up to date in the actual folder, /mdt.
So, I moved the content from /cvsroot/org.eclipse/www/mdt/ into /cvsroot/org.eclipse/www/modeling/mdt/ and removed the symlink between those folders, then created a header("Location: ...") redirect in /mdt to bounce from there into /modeling/mdt. Unfortunately, the website isn't refreshing at all anymore.
Also, I noticed that the group access is wrong in /cvsroot/org.eclipse/www/modeling/mdt:
-r--rwxr--+ 1 nickb modeling-home 13K 2006-10-30 14:07 index.php,v -r--rwxr--+ 1 nickb modeling-home 8.4K 2006-10-30 14:08 _projectCommon.php,v drwxr-sr-x+ 15 nickb modeling-home 648 2006-10-30 14:08 .

bug.short_desc: Shallow flag passed through on move

long_desc.thetext: If you call IFileStore.move and pass in the SHALLOW flag, it should be ignored. The LocalFile implementation of move sometimes calls super.copy and passes through the same arguments, so it's possible to get SHALLOW semantics during a copy. The shallow flag should not be propagated from move because it is not a valid parameter for the move method.
Correction: it is the base FileStore class that calls copy in its implementation of move.
Fixed.

bug.short_desc: [UX] Improve log import failure handling

long_desc.thetext:
Currently, log import is too unforgiving of errors and forces a user to start over from the beginining if import fails. It also gives an error message that is too cryptic to be of much use to anyone. The following changes should be made:
1. Improve the error message. The message should state that the log could not be imported and does not seem to match the adapter.
2. Once the import fails, the log is still shown in the left navigation, but cannot be modified. Users should be able to right-click on the file and change the filter in order to reimport the file.
Add bug 163437 as a dependent.

The description below is not very clear. Please replace with this. I am also duping the referenced requirement.
Currently, log import is too unforgiving of errors and forces a user to start over from the beginining if import fails. It also gives an error message that is too cryptic to be of much use to anyone. The following changes should be made:
1. Improve the error message. The message should state that the log could not be imported and does not seem to match the adapter. The messages should still be available-some users may have some use for them.
2. Once the import fails, the log is still shown in the left navigation, but cannot be modified. In icon should be displayed indicating that the log failed to import (we can provide). Users should be able to right-click on the file and go directly open the dialog that they openned in the import flow, and change the filter, version and other associated properties.
An extension point for other adapters is needed too.
*** Bug 163437 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Can you elaborate on step 2; I need a detailed step by step information of the expected flow. If the import log dialog opens and the user presses finish after changing this log file's properties then ALL current log set will reimported. Do you wnat to have this ? If not please explain the UI changes from a usability point of view that will help us avoid this
I also don't understand this comment >>>> An extension point for other adapters is needed too.

(In reply to comment #2) I agree the import error message should be improved, for example, explicitly say it's the wrong file type, invalid file path, etc. However, Should a 'failed' log file instance be created in the first place when a failure of a log import happens? Also, if we are given user a way to re-import, should that support be provided in the error dialog (eg. button 'retry'), or as a context menu in the failed log instance? If such support is available in error dialog, we may face an issue of error dialogs of different logs in a single import show up at different time instance. We need more information to proceed our design.

(In reply to comment #5)
You bring up a good point. Let's discuss the scenario from the start. 1. User open the Log Import wizard, specify some log files and types (see bug 161779 also), and hit the "Import" button
2. There is some problems with the import process. There should just be one error message for the whole import step. The error message should give a list of the problematic log files and the reasons why. Do not create the log entries (in the Navigator) for these problematic log files. In this case there is no need for the error icon in the Navigator.
3. Give the opportunity for the user to fix the problem by bringing up the wizard again if s/he chooses to do so (from the error message dialog). - The first page should be the "Log Files" page of the wizard - The wizard should remember the values entered by the previous import step. - Only the problematic log should be selected (checked) "Log Files" page. Some error indication would be needed to give visual clue to the user (icon next to the log entry) - The user will select one problematic log and click "Edit" button - The "Log type" page will be shown. There should be an error message at the top of the page to indicate which error it is and how to fix it. User will fix the error. - User will do the same with the next problematic log until all errors are fixed
Note that the flow above is based on the existing wizard. Bug 161779 may change the flow.
Let me know if this is fine.
raising priority per consumer's feedback.
Resolving this as WONTFIX because it is no longer required by the consumer that requested it.

bug.short_desc: Use Strings instead of IPaths in IIndex/IIndexFragment API

long_desc.thetext:
(Summary of initial discussion from cdt-dev list)
To facilitate the construction of relocatable PDOMs (bug 162172), references to files within the index should be derived from IPaths. However, since IPaths can be (de)serialized using IPath.toPortableString(), it is not necessary to force users of the IIndex API to use IPaths.

(More snippets from cdt-dev)
Markus wrote: Anyways I agree that it is possible to use a String to identify files at the level of IIndexFragments. It's just hard to do without knowing what the String is supposed to contain (full path, location, which format (slashes, backslashes)), but we can specify and document this.
For the API the clients have to use, I'd rather have them pass in IResources or ITranslationUnits, so they don't have to know how they have to convert those to a String to get correct results.

Would it be sufficient to document the format of the strings so that CDT clients will know what to pass in?
For remote parsing/indexing, we plan to use this feature in an environment where Eclipse is not running. The paths in the index will not be coming from IPaths so we need the flexibility of using something more generic like URIs (like EFS) or strings.

(In reply to comment #2) > Would it be sufficient to document the format of the strings so that CDT > clients will know what to pass in? Actually I don't see a problem with a method that just takes a string, as long as we offer an alternative (using ITranslationUnit or IFile) to the user. I tend to think that the indexer api turns out to be something more internal and that I might want to create an additional layer on top of it, that works with ITranslationUnits and ICElements rather than the IIndex stuff?

> I > tend to think that the indexer api turns out to be something more internal and > that I might want to create an additional layer on top of it, that works with > ITranslationUnits and ICElements rather than the IIndex stuff?
Yes, we do offer the ability for people to write their own indexer but this will be pretty rare. Other than dealing with ICElement deltas and writing entries into the index, there isn't much else they do.
I've posted a patch to https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=162172 that uses URIs in the IIndex APIs. (Its just for discussion purposes)
This was fixed together with bug 162172.

bug.short_desc: create rich editor for new JIRA tasks

long_desc.thetext:

You have not selected a valid project to create an issue in. "

Software Versions:

Eclipse SDK Version: 3.2.1 Build id: M20060921-0945
Running on Ubuntu Edgy 6.10
This is caused by Mylar not logging in to JIRA when you select "New Repository Task". If I log in to JIRA manually in the Eclipse web browser, it works.
There is no rich editor for Jira yet. You would have to live with web interface, so select project, etc. See bug 142869 for the rich Jira editor.
I made the note about the need to log in when using the web UI more explicit on the corresponding wizard page.
Since the JIRA connector has proper task data support and the API has a createIssue() call it should not be too hard to implement an editor. Is there anything to watch out for?
Nope, I think its all set to go!
Committed to CVS.

*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 142721 ***

bug.short_desc: Cannot search for Tasks: "No repository available"

long_desc.thetext:
I've created a JIRA repository which validates successfully. When I select Search->Search->Task Search I get a dialog saying, "No repository available, please add one using the Task Repositories view."
Upon opening the Task Repositories view, my repository is there and still validates successfully from Properties.
Software Versions:
Jira Core Services 0.9.1 Mylar Connector: JIRA 0.8 Mylar Focused UI 0.8.0 Mylar Task List 0.8.0
Eclipse SDK Version: 3.2.1 Build id: M20060921-0945
Running on Ubuntu Edgy 6.10

Task search was not implemented for JIRA in 0.8, but I'm happy to say that it will be available in tonight's dev build and in the 0.9 release scheduled for next Friday.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 162651 ***

bug.short_desc: Mylar garbles bugzilla product names in form display

long_desc.thetext: I name my products in bugzilla after the name of the site. Wiuth a long name (www.lumiance-lighting.com) the name appears as two entries: www.lumi and ance-lighting.com. Even after updating attributes from repository. This only affects the form view, not the browser view. Can this prevented or do I delete some local file to refresh anew.

Created an attachment (id=52959) screen shotd escribing bug
A flash file showing the bug.

Wow, cool video :)
Rob: looks related to bug 162853 ?

Please note that the same did NOT occur under 0.7 However it may some confused configuration file, I've looked in workspace/.mylar but no obvious targets for deleteionm or editing can be found. What should I delete before doing a Retrieve Attributes from Server or do I need to create everything again?
It looks like a bug, so beyond using the Task Repositories view's "Update Attributes" action on the popup menu you will not be able to do anything to remedy this.
*** Bug 162853 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Fixed. My configuration parser had a bug - it wasn't accounting for the case where the SAX parser would return only a portion of the attribute data. This was the cause of the splitting of some names into two. Thanks for sending your config rdf, that made tracking this down much easier.
Created an attachment (id=53153) mylar/context/zip

bug.short_desc: Product Configuration Manager can't resolve fragments in an eclipse extension location

long_desc.thetext:
In order to make the Fedora Eclipse packages LSB compliant, we are moving all of platform specific fragments from /usr/share/eclipse (the Eclipse install location) to /usr/lib/eclipse and making an eclipse extension location there. Right now we are moving these fragments to /usr/lib/eclipse/plugins:
org.eclipse.core.filesystem.linux.x86_1.0.0.v20060603.jar org.eclipse.platform.source.linux.gtk.x86_3.2.1.r321_v20060921-MGDh_08KUYM-Bvn org.eclipse.rcp.source.linux.gtk.x86_3.2.1.r321_v20060801-clWbqCmjexIWDqg org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.x86_3.2.1.v3235.jar
Everything seems to work well with this approach except for these two problems in the Product Configuration Manager:
1) The Product Configuration manager thinks that these 4 fragments are missing. 2) It's possible for a user to disable the extension location and therefore disable all those fragments. The next time the user starts Eclipse, it doesn't work because it can't find the swt fragment. The user must delete their configuration (i.e. 'rm -rf ~/.eclipse') to get Eclispe to start again.
For problem 1, if the OSGi framework can resolve the fragments, shouldn't the Product Configuration Manager be able to resolve the fragments? Fixing problem 1 might fix problem 2 because the Product Configuration Manager would then be able to detect that disabling the extension location with these fragments would invalidate the platform. Any thoughts here would be appreciated.

1/AFAIK, the update configurator/core cannot handle several extension locations for one feature.So creating a feature for those fragment could help.
2/Once the fragments are in a feature that problem may go away.

(In reply to comment #1) > 1/AFAIK, the update configurator/core cannot handle several extension locations > for one feature.So creating a feature for those fragment could help.
Our goal for Fedora Eclipse is to diverage as little as possible from the upstream release of the Eclipse SDK. Adding our own feature would go against this goal and would only solve problem 1 (more below).
> 2/Once the fragments are in a feature that problem may go away.
I don't think that this would solve problem number 2. How would the update manager know that a critical part of the platform is the feature we create? Of the two problems, I think problem number 2 is more severe because a user can invalidate their install.

I think you would either have to have everything the way eclipse packs it, or if you change the layout, create your own features. Which is prefectly fine, that is why feature were created in the first place.
Now, if you get you own feature layout, it should (i am not 100% sure) do with 1/. Once 1/ is solved the upate configurator should pick up those fragments all right, and should (hopefully) know that there are dependencies (either bundle level or you could define them feature level too) between the content of those features. And that should also deal with 2/.
Now there are also some constraints in colocation of features (and bugs, or "new and improved" functionalities in the update core/config) that may prohibit that to work out nicely anyway.:-\
But I doubt that you could be able to keep the feature the way they are, and move some bundles in separate locations. Afaik, a feature expects to have all of its plugins in one tree.

bug.short_desc: Too many open files on Windows

long_desc.thetext:
We are starting to see problems with Osgi opening too many files, the problem is typically exposed by launching eclipse inside of eclipse. Our product builds on top of (Eclipse and Webtools) adding a lot of more plugins.
The exceptions that we are seeing are similar to: - - - - - - - - - - - - STACKTRACE - - - - - - - - - - - !ENTRY org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility.registry 4 0 2006-10-11 08:46:08.744 !MESSAGE FrameworkEvent.ERROR !STACK 0 java.util.zip.ZipException: Too many open files C:\IBM\MyProduct\eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility.registry_3.2.1.R32x_v20060907\runtime_registry_compatibility.jar at java.util.zip.ZipFile.open(Native Method) at java.util.zip.ZipFile.<init>(ZipFile.java:238) at java.util.zip.ZipFile.<init>(ZipFile.java:268) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.util.SecureAction.getZipFile(SecureAction.java:226) ... ... - - - - - - - - - - - - STACKTRACE - - - - - - - - - - -
As a workaorund we are using -Dosgi.bundlefile.limit=100 as a VMArgument in the configuration. But eclipse-osgi should contain more reasonable defaults and not require this new parameter just to allow it to run.

you have to define reasonable. Setting at parameter has side effects that will disappoint other people. If we set the value to what you want, we'll get bug reports asking for it to be set to a differnet value. How can we win this game?

Is this not a duplicate of Bug 140549?
Business Partner using an IBM product built on the Eclipse + most of Callisto base (we add more of course). They have this problem when using a German language installation and trying to start a runtime workbench to test their plugins. So translations seem to drive this a bit as well as a PDE launch.
Why not pick a number that is 2X what Eclipse + Callisto needs, assuming that will be at least 100; then at least the "big boy" we have works when running in German.
Or try a circular test - a non-English Eclipse + Callisto layer and get a plugin or three in the workspace to test. That is what triggered the Partner problem. The product started fine, but you could not launch the runtime workbench.
If Eclipse + Callisto starts a runtime workbench in a non-English system, maybe you should double the number from there (if you can tell how many files were open). The rest of us need room to grow.

Resolving as dup of bug 140549. There really is no good answer for providing a default here. In testing some real products it was found the setting of osgi.bundlefile.limit = 100 had some real performance issues. In that particular situation a value above 200 seemed to give reasonable performance.
If we are forced to provide some default then I would lean toward a very high number (even above 500). But I'm not sure what the different file limits are of the different platforms we support. In the end we would likely need to supply a different default for each of the platforms we support.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 140549 ***

bug.short_desc: [Forms] IllegalArgumentException in BusyIndicator's busyThread.run due to GC being disposed

long_desc.thetext:
3.2
A user got the following when saving the contents of a forms-based editor that uses the busy indicator in the Form widget:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Argument not valid at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3358) at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3297) at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3268) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget.error(Widget.java:434) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Canvas.drawBackground(Canvas.java:97) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.forms.widgets.BusyIndicator$3.run(BusyIndicator.java:120) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.RunnableLock.run(RunnableLock.java:35) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Synchronizer.runAsyncMessages(Synchronizer.java:123) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.runAsyncMessages(Display.java:3141) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.readAndDispatch(Display.java:2843) at com.ibm.team.filesystem.ui.views.TeamPlacePart.updateBusy(TeamPlacePart.java:929) at com.ibm.team.filesystem.ui.views.TeamPlacePart.access$8(TeamPlacePart.java:919) at com.ibm.team.filesystem.ui.views.TeamPlacePart$5.changed(TeamPlacePart.java:436) at com.ibm.team.repository.rcp.ui.internal.utils.ChangeListenerList.notifyListeners(ChangeListenerList.java:60) at com.ibm.team.repository.rcp.ui.workingcopy.AbstractWorkingCopy.notifyListeners(AbstractWorkingCopy.java:85) at com.ibm.team.filesystem.ui.views.TeamPlaceWorkingCopy.setBusy(TeamPlaceWorkingCopy.java:571) at com.ibm.team.filesystem.ui.views.TeamPlaceWorkingCopy.access$0(TeamPlaceWorkingCopy.java:568) at com.ibm.team.filesystem.ui.views.TeamPlaceWorkingCopy$UIOperation$1.run(TeamPlaceWorkingCopy.java:93) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.RunnableLock.run(RunnableLock.java:35) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Synchronizer.runAsyncMessages(Synchronizer.java:123) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.runAsyncMessages(Display.java:3141) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.readAndDispatch(Display.java:2843) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.runEventLoop(Workbench.java:1914) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.runUI(Workbench.java:1878) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.createAndRunWorkbench(Workbench.java:419) at org.eclipse.ui.PlatformUI.createAndRunWorkbench(PlatformUI.java:149) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.ide.IDEApplication.run(IDEApplication.java:95) at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.PlatformActivator$1.run(PlatformActivator.java:78) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.internal.adaptor.EclipseAppLauncher.runApplication(EclipseAppLauncher.java:92) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.internal.adaptor.EclipseAppLauncher.start(EclipseAppLauncher.java:68) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:400) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:177) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39) at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25) at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:585) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.invokeFramework(Main.java:336) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:280) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:977) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:952)
Looks like an bug in the implementation of BusyIndicator. The busyThread's run method does:
final GC offScreenImageGC = new GC(offScreenImage); getDisplay().asyncExec(new Runnable() { public void run() { drawBackground(offScreenImageGC, 0, 0, loader.logicalScreenWidth, loader.logicalScreenHeight); } });
and the disposes offScreenImageGC when the while loop exits. If the GC gets disposed before the asyncExec runs, it will fail with the stack above.
Back link to Jazz work item: #11245.
